title: Building crypto vaults with Veda Co-Founder Sun Raghupathi

rawLines.text: free month free trial. Now today's
episode is around crypto vaults. So at
its core, what is VEDA?
VETA is the largest D5 vault platform.
Um so maybe we can start with what are
vaults? Vaults are basically tools for
abstraction, right? Def's
all kinds of different protocols,
bridges. Um you know, even people who've
been like working in DeFi for a long
time sometimes find it hard to navigate.
Vaults are basically a passive way for
users to earn yield in DeFi. They
abstract over all the complexity, all
the bridging and provide a simple
interface where users can just deposit
their assets and earn yield. And so it's
really amendable to like mass
distribution. In my view, vaults are the
missing piece for taking DeFi
mainstream. U VA is the leading vault
provider over three and a half billion
in TVL. Um we're we take a B2B approach.
So we work with chains, asset issuers,
protocols to allow them to build bespoke
yield products for their users.
So how does that sort of work? As in you
build like you create a set of code, it
works across maybe a certain number of
chains and you license people to like
use that code. Is is that it?
It's it's a little more than that,
right? So we have this um foundational
building block um which is our set of
smart contracts. We called it the boring
vault. It's this new architecture that
we built from the ground up. So a vault
is just a deployment of the boring vault
which with a bunch of off-chain services
that we provide as well, right? So
things like APIs for users to be able to
see what's going on, analytics, um SDKs
for front-end integration. So it's
really a full suite of services all the
way from smart contracts to actually
data that users consume to see what's
going on with their positions. We
provide that whole stack to our
partners.
Okay. And how secure or how battle
tested would you say your smart
contracts are?
Yeah. So, you know, just Veta canonical
deployments hold three and a half
billion in TVL. There's never been a
security incident on one of our
underlying smart contracts. I could say
a lot about why vaults are arguably more
secure than other kinds of D5
primitives. The short answer for this is
if you take something like a DEX or a
lending protocol, there's a million
things you can do with it, right? You
can compose different actions in
different ways. Um, you know, there's
weird things like flash loans. So
there's just this very large surface
area that it can be difficult to figure
out, you know, how do I safeguard this?
For vaults, it's super simple, right?
There's two public functions. There's
deposit and withdraw. So with that
surface area, you can build a ton of
safeguards into both the entry and the
exit to prevent um you know to mitigate
mitigate risk. Uh so our contracts are
pretty battle tested at this point.
We've been live for a little bit over a
year. Again, over three and a half
billion in TVL. Um, but there's also a
ton of projects that have built on top
of the boring vault standard. Uh,
there's there's over a dozen protocols
that have either forked the boring vault
or, you know, are working with us to
develop their own version of it. And,
you know, this is I I wouldn't be
surprised if the boring vault is one of
the most audited pieces of code in the
world because we've done a bunch of
audits ourselves, but every partner that
we uses also does their own audit. So,
there's just this compounding effect as
more and more people adopt a standard
for security of our of our smart
contracts.
Does that mean there's a sort of
potential uh I can't think of the word
but uh maybe like contagion risk in a
way like let's say like if there was an
issue with the core sort of smart
contracts that could then apply to all
of these vaults in one go
potentially right if there was some like
very critical fundamental logic error
that affected all of the vaults. Um one
like very conscious design choice that
we made is the core code is super
simple. It's like a 100 lines of code.
Like we built this with simplicity in
mind. So it is very unlikely that the
core vault itself has any logic error.
Number one, again it's very small
surface area for code. So um you know
there's been a lot of eyeballs on this
and users looking at it. But number two,
the architecture is super modular. So
it'd be pretty easy to like you know um
update and uh just swap out the the the
affected components if need be. Um so I
don't think it's a it's a major risk. Um
it's a very very simple and modular
architecture which means that it's easy
to upgrade if need be.
Okay. And then you mentioned like
complexities of exits. Uh reports coming
out that GMX may have just been hacked
for around 35 to $40 million. Uh we've
just seen that uh we believe it's GMX uh
team has sent an onchain message
offering a 10% white hat bounty and
acknowledging the exploit. Uh I haven't
confirmed that myself. that's a real
message, but um it does seem that uh
it's quite likely that it's been hacked.
Um do you do you have any thoughts on uh
on that taking place?
Yeah, I mean, first of all, like you
know, my my thoughts go out to to anyone
who's who's like in the protocol and uh
hacks are just rough and DeFi's matured
a lot, but it's still just part of the
game. Like we still have protocols
getting hacked almost every week. Um,
I'm not super familiar with what the the
hack is. It actually just came out

going to dig into it, but um, it's
interesting because GMX has been around
for a really long time, right? And
historically, it's had a pretty strong
track record. So, I'd have to assume
that this was some new logic or new code
that was introduced, but we'll we'll
just have to see. It's a it's, you know,
it's a tough situation.
Yeah. And then the one thing that I sort
of wondered about as it may be more of a
closer parallel was um the by bet hack
that involved safe. And now safe is
different but also similarly they focus
on multi-IGs
um trying to keep you know funds secure.
It's not too dissimilar to vaults. Um
and then obviously that was
the largest hack. I'd have to check but
I think so. Um,
do things like that sort of scare you at
how easy it is for something like that
to get through or is that just like a
very different example because that's
more of like a sort of custodial system?
So the important thing that the big
lesson from the safe hack is the smart
contracts were totally fine, right? It's
not that the safe multi-IG accounts were
compromised in any way at a smart
contract level. rather the hackers got
access to um Nosis' off-chain systems,
right? And they were able to do this
very very targeted attack that modified
data for a single target, right? In this
case, it was by bit. Um so there's a ton
of lessons there. Number one, it is
terrifying, right? Like that that
patience, the execution of the hack is
something that I don't think we've seen
in the past. U they could have, you
know, the exploers could have done this
to any safe account, right? they had
access to those systems, but they were
very patient. They were very targeted
and they just modified that one
transaction and that one address. So it
I I won't say it could have happened to
anyone because there are things that you
know um the BBE team could have done to
prevent it. Again, this type of exploit
has never been seen before. So I'm sure
Bobbit was following kind of standard
standard practices and not maybe you
know the exceptional practices that
would be required to prevent this. But
the lesson is that like off-chain
systems uh can be compromised period.
Right? Like if the if your smart
contract system or your protocol has a
failure point in an off-chain system,
that is that should automatically be
where you think hackers are going to go
first, right? Um and the the like design
lesson here is build your smart
contracts in a way that even if your
off-chain systems are compromised, it
does not lead to, you know, like loss of

really be easier for people to see
what's going on, right? Like the
transactions that they're signing, the
things they're executing. Um it's like,
you know, blind signing is just this
horrible thing that still is very
prevalent in the space. Um there hasn't

you cannot have a successful vault if

There's that whole practical

There's you know all kinds of standard

cleanText:
Free month, free trial. Now, today's episode is around crypto vaults. So, at its core, what is Veda?

Veda is the largest DeFi vault platform. Um, so maybe we can start with what are vaults? Vaults are basically tools for abstraction, right? DeFi's all kinds of different protocols, bridges. Um, and the the like design lesson here is build your smart contracts in a way that even if your off-chain systems are compromised, it does not lead to, you know, like loss of funds.
